comments.commentBody:
I really can not believe this article.
I travel all the time. Last year I spent the night in a not so nice motel near the Detroit airport due to a mechanical problem. The year before that while flying with my daughter we had a very scary aborted landing. Ended up landing at an airport 100 miles from our home There was chaos when we landed. We ended up on a bus and got home at 3AM. Would you want your child to deal with either of those situations alone? I am in my 40s and am a very experienced traveler- yes also all over the world- and there are times when I am overwhelmed in airports.
Our kids ask us when can they travel alone- we say "When you are 18".
Then my husband recounts when his parent sent him alone on a trip to Madrid from JFK. Bad weather sent the flight to Barcelona. They also saved money by not registering him with the airline. Now many years later he recalls his fear. it was kind strangers who helped him.
A parent who is too cheap to protect their child- I bet they are the same parents who sue the airlines when their child goes missing or worse.

At times like this too many people hesitate to take advice because they want to look after their possessions; but then forget to remember that their own lives are the most valuable possession they have.

Look after that precious possession & you'll all the more likely get through this danger/if any.

Safeness to all.

Reading many tributes since last night, Mr. Pogue's the best. He captures the essence of Steve Job's role not only in Apple but in shaping this highly Internet-focused and technology-oriented world.

Steve Job is not any ordinary CEO; he is indeed not replaceable--it is too bad that he has to leave earlier than he should at 50s. His leaving is not only a personal tragedy but a collective one. He certainly will be missed.

A tax cut for the lower and middle income earners pumps money back into the economy, since these people spend it on food, housing, transportation, etc.  Tax cuts for businesses and the wealthy just mean that they hold on to more savings.  We've seen this time and time again over the last 30 years, but for some reason people still believe in "trickle down" theory. Trickle down is a failure.  It's tax cuts for the lower and middle incomes that "trickle up."
How does putting ~$1k in people's pockets not help the economy?  I thought that was the thinking behind all those stimulus checks they wrote out not so long ago...?
Payroll tax cut... what a joke this tax cut was made for the middle class, anyone who is a hourly employee and makes 30,000 or under a year knows we got no break!!

"Federal officials have consistently overestimated the number of households that would be helped by their various housing assistance programs."
So ENFORCE IT. All such programs have failed to generate the intended assistance to borrowers because they are NOT MANDATORY!! The lenders are taking care of their shareholders, and now that lending practices are safely tightened, most all the prey of the predatory lenders are prevented from escaping into more reasonable loans. There is no incentive or inducement so there is no action, while homeowners die on the vine and foreclosures drag values down. B.O.A., Chase, et al count their profits and sleep well in the meanwhile. Force lenders to clean up their toxic leavings. After all, who is more responsible: the laypeople who took these loans, or the financial professional class who wrote them? Who should have seen this coming?
As for the hackneyed saw about irresponsible borrowers who bought homes too expensive for their means, it doesn't take an enormous principal debt to put you under if your interest rate is 8, 9, say 10% or more. My own purchase was "the cheapest house I've seen this year" according to my realtor, but I'm still barely above water, thanks to usurious terms. I know I'm not alone in taking a bad loan as a "bridge" only to find the door slammed behind when it was time to re-fi, despite conscientious credit hygiene. And how about questioning instead the wisdom of cutting off access to re-finance by tightening lending criteria after all these terrible loans were already out there??
I am in vehemently, rabidly in favor of a blanket refi plan for all subprime loans because:
1. Lenders could continue making reasonable profits on said loans.
2. Taxpayers pay $0.00.
3. Home values are stabilized.
4. Families are stabilized.
5. Usury is rejected as an acceptable form of business in America.

Seems like a multibillion dollar no brainer to me.

I started flying alone between the US and Europe when I was 12 years old (many years ago), and did so every summer for 4 years to spend a month with a host family.  It would have never crossed my or my parents' minds to use an escort - I was quite capable by that time.  Around age 16 was my first missed connection that required an overnight stay.  I negotiated with the airline to get into a nearby "fully booked" hotel, found a mutually agreeable new flight time the next day, and called my parents to let them know the new plan and that was that.  I think many kids can handle more than they're given credit for.

@Will: My last, as it often does, ran up against the character count. Liverpool's activities in the transfer market are a real puzzle to me. On several occasions since the window opened and King Kenny started flashing around all of those Red $ox bucks, I've been trying to engage Bakes, the most prominent Liverpool supporter who comments on this blog, but he refuses to weigh in. Jordan Henderson? And they've been playing him on the right wing, too. Charlie Adam is just about the same player as Stevie G is: a dead ball specialist who makes plays from the middle of the pitch and makes few tackles, most of which are ill-timed or badly executed. He absolutely can NOT play on the same pitch as Gerrard. And after considering the three guys I've mentioned, 'Pool still has no less than 10 more midfielders on the squad. And, unlike Arsenal, who tend to pick 'em on the green side, Liverpool looks to be shunting aside their young'uns, at least in the midfield. It looks like, other than Poulsen, for whom there obviously is neither want nor need, the bottom of the pecking order looks to be Spearing and Shelvey, the guys that they grew. And I don't get it, either, because in the preseason games that I saw, and from the end of last season, I see Spearing ahead of Lucas, whom I've never rated. But they have produced both Kelly and Flanagan as fullbacks. But Flanagan was responsible for not covering Larsson, allowing Sunderland to draw at Anfield. I rate Kelly ahead of Flanagan, and I might take either over the mortally overrated Glen Johnson. How long before the Kuyts and Meireles, who were the best players on the side, by far, last year, sour on playing behind Henderson and Downing, just because they're flavor of the week? Dissent derailed Man City two years ago, and contributed possibly to Chelsea's slump last season. 'Pool's playing with fire without a massive selloff.
Wish I could go over, but with one in college and another looking at grad school, we're, um, occupied.

The thing that's so compelling about Group A is that all four teams attack-a lot. It will be the sternest of tests for the back lines and the goalies, and they're an interesting group, too.
But there may never have been a Champions' League group with quite so much firepower:
Robben, Muller, Gomez and Ribery; Silva, Dzeko, Nasri and Aguero; Rossi, Nilmar and Cani; Cavani, Lavezzi and Hamsik. Yikes, the defenders are having cold sweats already.
I agree with TDK that if either Bayern or City fail to emerge, heads will surely roll, especially with all of the German past masters who are not shy about expressing their opinions, and with the final at the Allianz. And, deep in Bavaria, there may be an elemental distrust of Heynckes, who by history, is a Moenchengladbach man, and is on his third go round with Bayern. For sure, Bayern and City are favored to emerge, but either Napoli or Villarreal have a puncher's chance in any of those games, with accomplished goal getters Rossi, Nilmar and Cavani. It will be interesting to see it shake out. For once, Mancini will NOT be criticized for loading up on the defensive midfielders. And there is the possibility of some earth shaking tackles between Schweinsteiger and YaYa Toure.

Witness identification is but one tool used in the investigation of a crime and is subject to the same inaccuracies, biases, stresses and weaknesses in all human perception.  Not one witness I have ever interviewed, whether it was in hot pursuit or years after the event ever got everything right.   That's why we have forensics and evidence processing.  The investigative process is like the scientific process, but open to interpretation by investigators, prosecutors, defense attorneys, Judges, juries, the media and the public. That's why there are rules of evidence and court procedure. As science improves and trace evidence identifying a suspect, victim or witness gets down to the molecular level such as DNA evidence, witness identification is tested in better fashion and should be embraced.  Rolling up the wrong guy never solved a crime.  Don't forget the fiasco of the suppressed memory prosecutions that occurred when junk science replaced solid investigative and forensic evidence and innocent families were torn apart.

"You can’t send a company to prison."

You can jolly well tie up the board's and the insiders' holdings for a term of years. If they're not responsible for what goes on, who is? If you can't put the company in prison, put the capital in prison.

You can't send a company to prison, but you can send the CEO and the Board of Directors to prison. Why should Bernie Madoff be the only one in prison.

Once the CEO and the Board of Directors understand that they are responsible for how they run their company, they will make sure that they run a clean ship. They don't want to spend even 30 days in Riker's Island. These elite strongly believe that punishment is a deterrent to the poor, not for the wealthy and powerful.

The most telling line of all in this was 'and you can't put a business in jail.' Has'nt that become what this is all about-that any kind of deceit, any kind of malfesance, anything they choose to do, as a 'business', a so-called 'corporate citizen', they will at worst receive a fine?
Real people who do real work, who play by the rules that allow society to function, lose everything so these modern day pirates can add to bloated portfolios they ought never to have had in the first place. Did NOTHING to earn. No value added to legitimate enterprise, or to society as a whole, just a big freaking game by those too lazy to earn a real living by honest means.
If a guy with a gun holds you up and steals your wallet you have recourse. He is ultimately going to do some serious jail time. If a corporate 'citizen' holds you up with market manipulations and robs you blind,trashes those markets and the economies of whole countries,you ought to have the same expectation of punative action to be taken, not watch as they throw themselves a congratulatory bash,grease the palms of their enablers, while no doubt plotting how to do it all over again.
We would do well to take a leaf out of Korea's playbook on this one,put some ethics and accountability back in the world of high finance, but something tells me we won't. We sure haven't so far.

That is an unsustainable situation- the math is very simple and does not work.

@Robert: "We need well run and reasonably reserved banks who do properly underwritten lending. It is as simple as that but all the author wants to due is bash the all participants..."

All Simon is proposing is a transparent analysis of TBTF bank balance sheets to accurately ensure they're reasonably reserved. How did you determine "The proposed remedy will kill the patient but achieve the authors goal to reduce risk" from a generic request to ensure banks are adequately capitalized? I don't see any specifics in the article but if I missed the part where he proposed 1:1 leverage please let me know. Also, when did legitimate, accurate criticism become bashing?
